Key Arguments: The bill's definitions are broad and ambiguous, posing inherent dangers.
Restrictions on political debate, public health responses, and criticism of government are seen as un-Australian and a denial of free speech.
The bill exempts government communications from being labeled as misinformation or disinformation, which is viewed as Orwellian.
Penalties for digital platforms are excessively harsh, potentially leading to widespread censorship to avoid fines.
Censorship could affect discussions on topics like climate change, as illustrated by the experience of physicist John Clauser.
The only effective way to combat misinformation is through public refutation, not censorship.
The bill contradicts Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights regarding freedom of opinion and expression.
Notable Quotes: For me, introducing any restrictions that affect: political debate; the public health response to COVID-19; the supposed foreign interference in elections, and 'undermining' democracy—is abhorrent and totally un-Australian.

The fact that the bill denies individual citizens the right to criticise—yet explicitly exempts communication being issued from any level of government that may be considered misinformation or disinformation—demonstrates how Orwellian this law (if approved) will become.
I recognise that social media is rife with misinformation and disinformation; but the only way to combat it is to publicly refute it, not censor it.
